newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan, US say can't confirm N.Korea missile report.
newsitem.headline: Japan, US say can't confirm N.Korea missile report.

text.p: Japan and U.S. military authorities in Tokyo said on Wednesday they could not confirm reports that North Korea was preparing to test-fire a long-range ballistic missile into seas just off the Japanese coast.
Quoting unnamed U.S. officials, NHK public television and Jiji news agency said North Korea was planning to test-fire its Rodong-1 long-range ballistic missile into the Sea of Japan.
The missile had been moved to a launching place near the east coast of the communist country, the reports said.
The Rodong 1 is based on the Soviet Scud design used by Iraq in the 1991 Gulf War.
Jiji said a military delegation from the Middle East, apparently from Iran, had also arrived at the launching site.
North Korea planned the test-firing as part of a demonstration aimed at selling missiles to Iran, Jiji said.
Officials from Japan's Defence and Foreign ministries and U.S. forces in Japan would not confirm the reports.
In May 1993, North Korea shocked Japan by test-firing its Rodong-1 ballistic missile into waters just off the coast of the Noto peninsula in the Sea of Japan.
U.S. spy satellites caught the launch and tracked its trajectory, but Japan was caught off guard.
